questions.question_text_1: Which of the following teams in an software organization is primarily responsible for analyzing the data generated by users and various teams within the organization and helping the organization make better decisions?

questions.question_text_1: An organization has planned to develop a web application that will help its employees make better investment plans. For better understanding the features that employees want, the organization arranged interviews with a set of employees.  Identify the phase of the software development process that the software is in.

question_texts: Which of the following is/are true about versioned deployment?

options.option_text: In this strategy, the users are allowed to choose the versions of software theywant to use.
In this strategy, the changes are incrementally rolled out to a small subset ofusers.

In this strategy, a new production environment is created for the new versionof the software without affecting the current one, and after sufficient testing of the new version,the users are routed from the current environment to the new environment.
The strategy has the drawback of maintaining multiple versions.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are true about Test-Driven Development (TDD)?
question_texts: Which of the following is/are true about Test-Driven Development (TDD)?

options.option_text: TDD is especially used for agile processes.
In TDD, we express each of the requirements for the desired software productin the form of a test.
In TDD, we derive the tests from the code implementation.
In TDD, we write the minimum code to meet the needs of each test.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true about the staging environment of deployment?
question_texts: Which of the following is true about the staging environment of deployment?

options.option_text: It is primarily created for performing integration and system testing.
It is also known as live environment where all the users can interact with thedeployed system.
It is the local environment for individual developers that provides IDEs andother tools.
It exactly reassembles the production environment, and it runs on a remotemachine.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose one of the hosting service providers has a server with an 8-core processor and 32 GB of RAM, which is sliced into 8 virtual machines (VMs) such that each VM includes a 1-core processor and 4 GB of RAM. The VMs also include software layers for deploying web applications. The service provider offers these VMs to its clients to host their web applications.  Which kind of hosting option is offered by the service provider?
question_texts: Suppose one of the hosting service providers has a server with an 8-core processor and 32 GB of RAM, which is sliced into 8 virtual machines (VMs) such that each VM includes a 1-core processor and 4 GB of RAM. The VMs also include software layers for deploying web applications. The service provider offers these VMs to its clients to host their web applications.  Which kind of hosting option is offered by the service provider?

question_texts: Consider a web application that uses Gzip to compress static pages so that the performance of the application can be improved.   In this scenario, which performance optimization strategy is in use?

options.option_text: Quick loading and rendering of web pages

questions.question_text_1: What is the main objective of sprint review in agile project management?
question_texts: What is the main objective of sprint review in agile project management?

options.option_text: To decide which work is to be done in the current sprint and how the chosenwork will be done.
To prioritize the work for the development team.
Team demonstrates what they have completed in the given sprint.
To evaluate the last sprint - team dynamics, processes, tools etc.

questions.question_text_1: An organization has provided a web application that employees can use to apply for leaves as well as manage holidays and leaves efficiently. The interface displays a calendar for the employee to choose their dates when completing the leave application. The calendar disables all weekends and official holidays of the organization.  Which of the following heuristics of UI design is satisfied by the mobile app?
question_texts: An organization has provided a web application that employees can use to apply for leaves as well as manage holidays and leaves efficiently. The interface displays a calendar for the employee to choose their dates when completing the leave application. The calendar disables all weekends and official holidays of the organization.  Which of the following heuristics of UI design is satisfied by the mobile app?

questions.question_text_1: Consider that an organization developed an IDE for a new programming language. However, the developers avoided implementing the shortcut keys that are usually used in all the popular IDEs for functionalities like select, select all, cut, copy, paste, etc. and instead implemented some new shortcut keys.  Which of the following usability goals is not satisfied by the design of the IDE?
question_texts: Consider that an organization developed an IDE for a new programming language. However, the developers avoided implementing the shortcut keys that are usually used in all the popular IDEs for functionalities like select, select all, cut, copy, paste, etc. and instead implemented some new shortcut keys.  Which of the following usability goals is not satisfied by the design of the IDE?

questions.question_text_1: A software company has to develop a smart meter that, along with recording the electric consumption information, also provides services like monitoring consumption behavior, automatic billing, etc. The development team has to build the software that is strongly coupled with the hardware of the smart meter. The company applies COCOMO model for calculating the effort to develop the system.  The values for the constants in the COCOMO model for the different types of the project are as follows:  • Organic project: a = 2.4, b = 1.05 • Semi-organic project: a = 3.0, b = 1.12 • Embedded project: a = 3.6, b = 1.20  Considering the source code of 2,00,000 lines and effort adjustment factor = 1.48, what is the final estimated effort for the project?
question_texts: A software company has to develop a smart meter that, along with recording the electric consumption information, also provides services like monitoring consumption behavior, automatic billing, etc. The development team has to build the software that is strongly coupled with the hardware of the smart meter. The company applies COCOMO model for calculating the effort to develop the system.  The values for the constants in the COCOMO model for the different types of the project are as follows:  • Organic project: a = 2.4, b = 1.05 • Semi-organic project: a = 3.0, b = 1.12 • Embedded project: a = 3.6, b = 1.20  Considering the source code of 2,00,000 lines and effort adjustment factor = 1.48, what is the final estimated effort for the project?

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **Software Engineering** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **1. Core Topics & Concepts**
### **A. Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC)**
- **Phases**:
  - **Requirement Gathering** (e.g., interviews, surveys).
  - **Design** (e.g., UML diagrams, prototypes).
  - **Development** (e.g., coding, version control).
  - **Testing** (e.g., black-box, white-box, TDD).
  - **Deployment** (e.g., staging, production, versioned deployment).
  - **Maintenance** (e.g., bug fixes, updates).
- **Key Models**:
  - **Agile** (Sprints, Scrum, Kanban).
  - **Waterfall** (Sequential phases).
  - **Prototyping** (Storyboards, paper prototypes, digital mock-ups).

### **B. Testing & Debugging**
#### **Testing Types**
| **Black-Box Testing** | **White-Box Testing** |
|-----------------------|-----------------------|
| Equivalence Partitioning | Branch Coverage |
| Boundary Value Analysis | Path Coverage |
| Decision Tables | Statement Coverage |

- **Test-Driven Development (TDD)**:
  - Write tests **before** code.
  - Red-Green-Refactor cycle.
  - Ensures **minimal code** to pass tests.

#### **Debugging Strategies**
| Strategy | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| **Forward Debugging** | Follows execution flow to find incorrect state. |
| **Backward Debugging** | Traces back from failure to find root cause. |
| **Profiling** | Measures execution time/frequency (performance debugging). |
| **Logging** | Records program events for analysis. |

- **Cyclomatic Complexity (McCabe’s Metric)**:
  - Measures code complexity via **decision points (if, loops, etc.)**.
  - Formula:
    \[
    M = P + 1 \quad \text{(where } P = \text{number of decision points)}
    \]
  - Example: `isPrime()` function has **3** (2 `if` + 1 loop).

#### **Error vs. Failure vs. Fault vs. Debugging**
| Term | Definition |
|------|-----------|
| **Error** | Human mistake (e.g., wrong logic). |
| **Fault (Bug)** | Manifestation of error in code. |
| **Failure** | Observable incorrect behavior. |
| **Debugging** | Process of finding and fixing faults. |

---

### **C. Software Design Principles**
#### **SOLID Principles**
| Principle | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| **Single Responsibility (SRP)** | A class should have **one reason to change**. |
| **Open-Closed (OCP)** | Open for **extension**, closed for **modification**. |
| **Liskov Substitution (LSP)** | Subclasses must be **substitutable** for base class. |
| **Interface Segregation (ISP)** | Clients shouldn’t depend on **unused interfaces**. |
| **Dependency Inversion (DIP)** | Depend on **abstractions**, not concretions. |

#### **Design Patterns**
| Pattern | Purpose | Example |
|---------|---------|---------|
| **Strategy** | Encapsulates interchangeable algorithms. | `LogManager` + `FileLogger`/`DBLogger`. |
| **Facade** | Simplifies complex subsystem interactions. | Unified API for payment gateways. |
| **Adapter** | Converts incompatible interfaces. | Legacy system integration. |

#### **Coupling & Cohesion**
| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **Content Coupling** | Module depends on **internal data** of another. |
| **Common Coupling** | Modules share **global data**. |
| **Control Coupling** | Module passes **control flags**. |
| **Data Coupling** | Modules share **data parameters**. |

---

### **D. Project Management & Agile**
#### **Agile Ceremonies**
| Ceremony | Purpose |
|----------|---------|
| **Sprint Planning** | Decide **what** and **how** to do in sprint. |
| **Daily Standup** | Sync on progress/blockers. |
| **Sprint Review** | **Demo** completed work. |
| **Sprint Retrospective** | Reflect on **process improvements**. |

#### **Risk Management**
- **Risk Priority** = **Probability × Impact**.
- Example:
  - **Insufficient domain knowledge (0.6 × 2 = 1.2)** > **Personnel shortfall (0.5 × 2 = 1.0)**.

#### **Project Management Tools**
- **JIRA**, **Pivotal Tracker**, **Trello**.

---

### **E. Deployment & Cloud Computing**
#### **Deployment Strategies**
| Strategy | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| **Versioned Deployment** | Users choose software version. **Drawback**: Maintain multiple versions. |
| **Blue-Green Deployment** | New version runs alongside old; switch traffic when ready. |
| **Canary Release** | Gradually roll out to **subset of users**. |

#### **Cloud Hosting Models**
| Model | Description | Example |
|-------|-------------|---------|
| **IaaS** | Rent **infrastructure** (VMs, storage). | AWS EC2. |
| **PaaS** | Rent **platform** (OS, runtime). | Heroku, Google App Engine. |
| **SaaS** | Rent **software** (ready-to-use). | Gmail, Slack. |

#### **Performance Optimization**
| Technique | Example |
|-----------|---------|
| **Caching** | Store frequent queries (Redis). |
| **Compression** | Gzip for static files. |
| **Task Queues** | Offload heavy tasks (Celery). |

---

### **F. Usability & UI Design**
#### **Usability Goals (Nielsen’s Heuristics)**
| Goal | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **Learnability** | Easy to **learn** (e.g., standard shortcuts). |
| **Efficiency** | Quick to **use** after learning. |
| **Memorability** | Easy to **remember** how to use. |
| **Error Prevention** | Avoid mistakes (e.g., disabled weekends in calendar). |
| **Recoverability** | Help users **recover from errors**. |

#### **Prototyping Types**
| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **Storyboard** | Hand-drawn **comic-style** flow. |
| **Paper Prototype** | Low-fidelity **physical mockup**. |
| **Digital Mockup** | High-fidelity **interactive design**. |

---

## **2. Key Equations**
1. **Cyclomatic Complexity**:
   \[
   M = P + 1 \quad \text{(Decision points + 1)}
   \]
2. **COCOMO Effort Estimation**:
   \[
   \text{Effort} = a \times (\text{KLOC})^{b} \times \text{EAF}
   \]
   - **Embedded Project**: \( a = 3.6, b = 1.20 \).
   - Example: \( 3.6 \times (200)^{1.20} \times 1.48 \approx 3075 \) person-months.
3. **Risk Priority**:
   \[
   \text{Risk Score} = \text{Probability} \times \text{Impact}
   \]

---

## **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **Graph 1: Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC)**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Requirement Gathering] --> B[Design]
    B --> C[Development]
    C --> D[Testing]
    D --> E[Deployment]
    E --> F[Maintenance]
    F -->|Feedback| A
```

### **Graph 2: Testing & Debugging**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Testing] --> B[Black-Box]
    A --> C[White-Box]
    B --> D[Equivalence Partitioning]
    B --> E[Boundary Value Analysis]
    C --> F[Branch Coverage]
    C --> G[Path Coverage]
    A --> H[Debugging]
    H --> I[Forward]
    H --> J[Backward]
    H --> K[Profiling]
```

### **Graph 3: SOLID Principles**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[SOLID] --> B[Single Responsibility]
    A --> C[Open-Closed]
    A --> D[Liskov Substitution]
    A --> E[Interface Segregation]
    A --> F[Dependency Inversion]
```

### **Graph 4: Deployment Strategies**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Deployment] --> B[Versioned]
    A --> C[Blue-Green]
    A --> D[Canary]
    B --> E[Multiple Versions]
    C --> F[Traffic Switch]
    D --> G[Gradual Rollout]
```

### **Graph 5: Cloud Hosting Models**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Cloud Computing] --> B[IaaS]
    A --> C[PaaS]
    A --> D[SaaS]
    B --> E[VMs, Storage]
    C --> F[Runtime, OS]
    D --> G[Ready-to-Use Software]
```

### **Graph 6: Agile Workflow**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Sprint Planning] --> B[Development]
    B --> C[Daily Standup]
    B --> D[Sprint Review]
    D --> E[Demo]
    B --> F[Sprint Retrospective]
    F --> G[Process Improvements]
```

### **Graph 7: Design Patterns**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Design Patterns] --> B[Strategy]
    A --> C[Facade]
    A --> D[Adapter]
    B --> E[Interchangeable Algorithms]
    C --> F[Simplify Subsystem]
    D --> G[Interface Conversion]
```

---
## **4. Exam Tips**
- **Testing**: Know the difference between **black-box** (behavioral) and **white-box** (structural) testing.
- **Debugging**: **Forward debugging** follows execution; **profiling** measures performance.
- **SOLID**: **Liskov Substitution** = subclasses must replace base class without breaking functionality.
- **Deployment**: **Versioned deployment** allows user choice but requires maintaining multiple versions.
- **COCOMO**: For **embedded systems**, use \( a = 3.6, b = 1.20 \).
- **Usability**: **Prevent errors** (e.g., disabled weekends) > **learnability** (standard shortcuts).
